content.webTitle: My veggie box lets me be a better person than I actually am | Alyx Gorman

fields.headline: My veggie box lets me be a better person than I actually am
fields.bodyText: Supermarkets are palaces of distraction. The beeping. The PA announcements. The fluorescent lights. The deliberately disorientating layouts. The way you have to crouch to reach the cheapest item and constantly resist the bright and shiny objects placed right at eye level. They’ve been socially engineered over decades to make you spend more than you’d like to, on things you don’t need. Even for competent adults it’s meant to be tough. I am not a competent adult. I am highly distractible. One look at a bag of rotisserie chicken and I’ll flash back 15 years to my time behind the checkout counter, bodily resisting the urge to vomit as I swiped whiffy charcoal chooks through the scanner on an underage hangover. Even when I enter with a meticulously planned list, I can’t stick with it. Another thing I’m too distracted for? Writing a meticulously planned grocery list. All this before we even contemplate the ethics. The palm oil, unfair labour practices, out-of-season figs and acres of unnecessary plastic. In season two of Fleabag, when Phoebe Waller-Bridge got down on her knees in a confessional booth and said “I just think I want someone to tell me how to live my life”, it could have been me, on aisle three, seconds from requiring a clean up. So I submitted myself to a higher power. I abandoned the vanity of deciding what to eat. I abandoned the torment of procuring it. Every Sunday morning, my partner and I undertake a sacrament. We walk to the farmer’s market and pick up a veggie box. If this activity sounds painfully middle-class, you’d be right. But just because it’s got the trappings of bourgeois virtue-signalling doesn’t mean it’s not economical. For $44 a week, we get more than enough fruit and vegetables to feed two adults, and a carton of 10 eggs, from cheerful chickens. The veggie box is comprised of whatever’s cheap and plentiful week to week – which means whatever is currently in season. When we planned our meals in advance and shopped for groceries in the supermarket, our food bills were far higher. Whatever’s in the box forms the central basis of our meals for the week. We do not choose what we’ll eat. The box chooses for us – we just augment its contents with protein and spice. Often that protein is the eggs, from the box. The veggie box allows me to be a better person than I actually am. I do not eat local, seasonally sourced produce of my own volition. The box makes me do it. I do not fit in a five-a-day because I have the willpower to make healthful choices – I do it because vegetables are the only thing in the house, and thus the easiest thing to eat. Sign up to receive the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning I did not learn to pickle leftover produce because food waste is a climate scourge, I did it because otherwise the contents of the next box will look over my crisper with judging, potato eyes and find their accomodation lacking. I do not home-dry fresh chamomile for tea because it sounds like a lovely thing to do (it is), I do it because there was chamomile in the box, and so the chamomile must be consumed. At the moment, I’m reading Wendy Wood’s Good Habits Bad Habits. In the book she details how much of our day is spent in thoughtless automaticity. We run along tracks we’ve already carved without much care and attention. These tracks can be good for us, or they can be profoundly destructive – it all depends on our environment. So much of the environment that’s built for us is designed to trap us into making the worst possible choices. To pick the bright and shiny objects that have been set for us at eye level. What we think of as convenient is actually draining – it drains our health, our wallets and our environmental resources. A cheap, seasonal veggie box is a different kind of habit. It places that choice in the hands of a person that knows best – in my case farmer Hapi and his wife Cath – and allows me to repeat the benefits of their good decision making. Sure, there’s joy to be found in deciding what you’ll cook for the week – but for me, that joy can only flourish amid constraints. The veggie box means I no longer have to deliberate at the grocery store – by robbing me of choice, it has given me freedom.
